comments.commentBody: So called "tiny parties" are a fundamental expression of democracy. Those who see the 2 established parties as tweedle dum and tweedle dee have the right,nay the obligation, to protest, in hopes of seeking a newer world.

I clicked recommend because I am not happy with the voter suppression, on which I will comment in more detail later.

But now, I have to mention Article I, Section 4 (AI, S4) of the Constitution: “The times, places, and manner of holding elections for senators and representatives, shall be prescribed in each state by the legislature thereof: but the congress may at any time by law make or alter such regulations, except as to the places of choosing senators.”

Just as with one part of the 2nd Amendment (“right of the people”) is emphasized over another (“well-regulated militia”), it seems the first part of Article I Section 4 (“each state”) is emphasized over another (“the congress may…by law make”).
how would a voter prevent those kinds of fraud?
Charles W - would you please provide evidence that black people are being bussed to vote twice.  Good grief, where do you get this stuff?

The basis of democracy is the right of every citizen to cast one vote. A successful democracy ensures that the system is untainted by fraud and coersion; and that the citizens are informed enough about the issues to cast a thoughtful vote for the candidate who best represents both their own interests and the interests of the nation as a whole, as they percieve it. All citizens should have a keen interest in voting under these circumstances and the turn out should be quite high.

The current issue of 'voter suppression', seems to me to be the penultimate step to the loss of democracy. The ultimate step would be loss of voting altogether.

With billions of dollars spent on advertising, outright lying and cheating having happened for decades, and the loss of a cohesive society I don't think that a lot of 'democracies' can be realistically described as such today, including the one in the country I live in.

Ignorance of issues, partisan warfare that takes no notice of the good of society but only the chance for each candidate to enrich themselves in one way or another, will be the death of what was a wonderful dream.

I think we all need another revolution. One that will really empower each citizen with enough real knowledge to be able to cast a meaningful vote. We cannot be individual nations anymore. As our economies go global, so our thinking has to as well. Perhaps we can make more 'human' societies for us all, one nation at a time.

Voter apathy will continue to be a problem. A big one indeed.
A sensible way, but extremely difficult to bring about, is to have a law, which would stick without the US supreme court VETOING it, is to pass a bipartisan mandated law with a wide margin, to impose a significant fine to those who do not vote, as in Australia.
I am for voter photo ID, based on common sense, and not discriminatory in a draconian way so that a huge number of poor and not well-educated can't have it. The Democratic argument of identifying voter ID with voter suppression is not right, though I am a loyal very liberal Democrat.

i agree R,Perth
it really doesn't address the problems at all... i just get tired of this 'issue'... it should not even be an issue ...
a photo id is required for everything in this country except buying a gallon of milk with cash.
we have real problems that involve all of america and we can't be stopping along the trail to argue and devise special rules and laws for every little member of every group that can't keep up, at the expense of all the rest who do.
DB, every time I  see that "both parties" comment, I disregard it as someone who does not follow politics closely. The voter suppression bills are all by one party, the Republcians.

I'll disagree. National Popular Vote would be a disaster for the smaller states - why campaign in, say, Wyoming, Montana, or Vermont, when, by taking the top 5 states and top 10 cities, a candidate can get elected?

The Electoral College was set up to ensure that a President not only had popular support, but had support across the country. Better than the National Popular Vote would be for more states to follow Nebraska and Maine and move from "Winner Take All" to allocation of electors by Congressional District, with the top vote-getter getting the two state electors. That would force the candidates to move out of the big cities in those states as well, and would change the dynamic.
I'll agree with moving away from voting machines.  At most, they should be used to help the disabled create a paper ballot - and that paper ballot is the ONLY thing that is counted.

Our voting system is shameful. We should begin by supporting the'' National Popular Vote"' movement (google it_. Next we should do what the Dutch decided to do last month-throw the voting machines in the garbage. Then we should do what the Germans and the Canadians do-count the votes by hand !

Trina, the point is that the REAL things people could do to make a change are NOT drinking bottles or cloth grocery sacks -- they are things like "having one baby and not 3 babies". And people won't do those kind of sacrifices. They think if they recycle, or buy organic veggies then it's OK to drive a giant SUV or vacation in Europe (massive jet fuel expenditure).

Interesting point. I buy nearly all our clothing and household items from estate sales and thrift shops -- at a fraction of cost new -- BUT I can only do this because MOST people buy things at the store. There isn't enough thrift shop stuff for EVERYBODY to buy.

In fact, in this recession more and more people are buying at estates sales and thrift stores -- meaning, the prices have gone up and the selection decreased markedly. A few more customers, and NOBODY will find anything nice or a bargain there -- and it will stop again.

You certainly cannot expect to find a working iPhone or decent electronics this way -- people don't sell that stuff unless it breaks or goes so out of compatibility that it is useless. For example, I had to DISCARD a working computer (after many years of use), when the company had no upgrade for it; another had to go when it no longer could use modern browsers to go on the internet.

Interesting thought. 40 years ago, we had our trash in reusable galvanized steel cans -- you dumped your trash right in, and the garbage man tipped it into a large truck and returned your can. Very environmentally sound!

As you said, it was LESS trash than today -- things had less packaging. Paper refuse was burned in an incinerator -- my house has a brand new, almost unused model from the late 50s (aqua!). But it's illegal to use it now.

Glass bottles were too precious to toss -- you returned to them to the store for a few cents rebate. This was mostly done by children for the pocket money -- which we then spent on soda or candy.

Instead of plastic, we lined waste baskets with paper sacks from the supermarket -- so they had a 2nd usage. Dog poop was picked up with old newspapers, which also lined bird cages.

Grandma religiously saved TIN FOIL and string and rubber bands -- oh, and she had closet full of margarine tubs to be used as leftover containers.

We don't need to reinvent the wheel -- these COMMON SENSE solutions could be easily returned to!!!!

Note: my city NOW forbids garbage cans and forces us to use plastic trash bags (which the raccoons cheerfully tear up, making a mess!) and expensive paper sacks for grass and yard clippings. In "progress", they have made things a hundred times LESS environmentally sound.

Barbara, sadly you CANNOT fix most modern new electronics (and it is increasingly hard to fix even CARS). Why? instead of simple metal parts, they use complex circuit boards. One thing burns out, the whole unit is ruined.

Things like toasters and small appliances are often designed NOT to ever be opened -- the innards are cheap plastic crap (from guess where????) -- they do not use universal parts like screws and washers.

My dad was an engineer -- the old school type -- and he greatly lamented this. He used to get great pleasure -- no environmental issues -- out of fixing a toaster or coffee maker, or repairing a lawn mower. He loved to pick up things from the trash or Goodwill and make them work again! But you simply can't do this today. And badly made, cheap thin plastic items don't even look good after a few years -- they discolor, melt, warp.

If you shop vintage (and I do this a lot), it is shocking how much better things were made even as recently as 15 years ago. For example, that recently you could buy well-designed US MADE stainless steel flatware at all price points -- quality stuff. Today it is all made in China, and out of substandard stainless that has no nickel in it -- so it pits and rusts. You can't tell unless you know the difference between 18/8 stainless and 18/0 -- not many do.

Another note: that big flat screen TV gulps 5 times as much power as your boxy old antenna TV.

Remember this discussion is happening almost exclusively among the "4%" -- the wealthiest Americans, who have LOTS of choices and the time to do things like carefully go to the Whole Foods or the gourmet market and pick out the baby heirloom organic veggies.

Most Americans live on the margins -- they struggle to get by on a paycheck and an income of roughly $50K (or LESS). They don't have these options or choices -- if organic milk is $9 a gallon and regular milk is $3 a gallon, we are drinking regular milk, period.

Those "organic cotton dresses" are usually a couple hundred dollars, plus are dowdy and don't hold up in the wash -- the cotton is organic, but cheap and thin. It doesn't launder well. Again, if you are middle class or working class, and you have to dress a family of five people, including 3 kids -- you will choose the cheap Chinese clothing from Target that is affordable and the environment be darned.

Your allegation that DOGS have a bigger carbon footprint than an SUV -- I'd have to see some references and articles to even partly believe that. I have a dog and I'd say her carbon footprint is nearly nothing. She certainly does not consume fossil fuel like an SUV!

I do agree that skimping on paper towels or separating your trash is silly if you take a European vacation by air travel -- and I can think of several people I know in this category. (This is also why carbon offsets will NEVER work.)

Let me know when you see affluent, urban, hip Americans (or Europeans) who give up AIR TRAVEL to "save the environment". Won't happen -- they are addicted to the pleasures of travel, and do not have the time to go any other way but by air.

As far as "unblemished foods" -- the dull ordinary markets I shop at (in the Midwest, not "Paris France") have bins at the sides of the veggie section, with bruised items at less than half price -- sometimes even FREE. They are great for soups -- the bruised overripe bananas are great for banana bread. Most old-time Depression-era grannies knew this well.

However, you can't charge Whole Foods prices but give people damaged produce -- it won't sell unless it is very very cheap.

Undiluted white vinegar makes a terrific cleaner. It's cheap, non-toxic & available in grocery stores everywhere. It's my "green" cleaner of choice! I have a cat, and it's "go outside, eat some grass, come in the house and puke on the carpeting" season. White vinegar really helps keep things fresh & unstained. Plus, my cat doesn't like the smell. Try it, you might like it.

I sympathize, but this really makes no sense when scaled up. People wear clothes and wear them out. Vehicles wear out. Shoes disintegrate. Appliances wear out. We collectively should be doing vastly better than we are, but if everyone stopped buying right now, the ensuing depression would be more than you might wish for. Maybe in New York a person can get by on castoffs, but it is only because of the profligate ways of your fellow city dwellers that the trash you covet is available. Also, your position is fine for a resident of a wealthy country, but what about the literally billions of fellow humans who scrape by on almost nothing? Even redistributing material things from the First to the Third World would soon run into transportation logistics that require more stuff to be made, as well as energy expended.

to Wallace Conner:  Shopping can be civic engagement, though.  Some people make a point of only buying food from local sources, at local farmer's markets or from their neighbor's gardens.  It takes a high degree of commitment and dedication to live this way, but some people do, nevertheless.

Unless it makes everybody feel good and distracts them from dealing with larger human problems.  Separating bottles and cans, newsprint and plastic is society's solution to being "responsible."  Again, government policy is what it is going to take, and working on a global scale is what is necessary.  The household level of recycling is like shooting rabbits with a cannon.  Sure, you get the rabbit, but at what cost?

That article in the NYT was many years ago and it was entitled "Recycling is Garbage."  It was well-researched and made rather shocking points---such as we use more energy to wash a ceramic coffee cup than to manufacture a styrofoam throw-away.  The author also made the point with precise statistics that landfills were not a problem and would not be a problem into the future.  His best point was that we have far more serious problems we should be addressing than separating trash and going to the local recycling center so that we can feel self-righteous.

If you really want to buy "green" then I suggest you stop wasting money on organic foods and other petty gimicks and stop buying products from countries with dirty energy sources, with China as an example. Altough I did not miss the point of the article, and it is very true; but for the next generation are growing up in a concerned and aware environment and hopefully will end up changing the culture of industry in a sort of 'what were they thinking' fasion (the market needs to be green first).

Great post.

in the work to raise awareness for "Less Cancer", Less Incidences of Cancer as opposed to more treated cancer. I ask people and communities to look to the environment and its impact on human health.

Today we live in a time that since 1975 we have a 60% increase in leukemia for children under age 14 and a 40% increase in brain cancers for children under 14.

Not to mention a whole host of other illnesses connected to the environment that would include Asthma, Birth defects, Developmental disorders, obesity and diabetes.

We must support those products not associated with increased risk for either human health and the environment. Consumers have shown exactly how powerful they are by supporting the organic markets.

Since the Organic markets have exploded U.S. sales of organic food and beverages have grown from $1 billion in 1990 to $26.7 billion in 2010.

Because of the support that Certified Organic has received we currently have farming than that bans polluting by way of using , synthetic fertilizers, sewage sludge, irradiation, and genetic engineering . Certified organic acreage in the United States reached more than 4.8 million acres in 2008.

Policy, business practices and consumers all have important roles in the shift towards change when it comes to human health and the environment.

Keep up the good work- I am grateful for all of you participating in this discussion- its an important issue.

Bill Couzens, Founder Less Cancer

Notice that you're suggesting greening people's consumption choices at the margins. Green cleaners, organic food, more energy efficient appliances. But people don't make the leap from this to downsizing their homes, giving up on air travel, abandoning their TV, swearing off pet ownership, giving up meat, and vowing to have only one child. These are entitlements of the consumer class and if there is a greener version then they might consider them but if not, well it's my right to be cool in the summer and fly off for vacations at luxurious island resorts.

But in a world of 7 billion where runaway climate change is poised to kill or displace millions and other ecosystem services are also unraveling, the idea that slight greening of the consumer economy will save us is absolutely absurd. Civic action at a scale never yet seen in human history is the only thing that will prevent the societal collapse that is increasingly probable. Consider that when choosing to work more hours to buy an organic cotton dress instead of patching one's old dress and then going off to protest.

Erik Assadourian, Transforming Cultures Project Director, Worldwatch Institute, www.transformingcultures.org

I don't know. When the organic movement became mainstream a few years ago we quickly witnessed corporations buying out smaller companies, or at least large shares within the companies. Honest Tea - Coca Cola. Kashi - GM (I think...forget, too lazy to google.) So on. It seems like the movement was started and taken over by big corporations. Indeed, even NYTimes wrote an article about this a while back: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/08/business/organic-food-purists-worry-ab... .

So partly, how is it a good thing to buy USDA organic products if it's just going to the bigger corporations who use those funds just to make bigger profits from the organic market, while changing the definitions of what organic is?

As this occurred/occurs, we then see the likes of Alice Waters grow in popularity and the rise/renewal of localvorism. Don't get me wrong I'm not 100% localvorian myself, but I am pretty close. I belong to 3 CSAs, grow some of my own stuff and buy most of my meat locally. I subscribe to the notion of recycling, reusing, etc. This is what I think is some what more important. To get the public more in tune with composting, recycling etc. But there needs to be an entry point some where along the line. Mine was Whole Foods which got me started up with my CSA memberships, which got me started with composting practices, and growing my own foods. So, stores like Whole Foods to me are a good entry point to retraining the consumers.

The emerging consensus on this is not how many paper bags you recycle, but how many children you don't have.

2009 paper by Murtaugh and Schlax
"The summed emissions of a person’s descendants, weighted by their relatedness to him, may far exceed the lifetime emissions produced by the original parent. Under current conditions in the United States, for example, each child adds about 9441 metric tons of carbon dioxide to the carbon legacy of an average female, which is 5.7 times her lifetime emissions."
